hints.Matrices: A rectangular array of numbers, symbols, or expressions, arranged in rows and columns.
hints.Vectors: An object that has both magnitude and direction, and follows the laws of vector addition.
hints.Scalar Multiplication: The multiplication of a vector by a scalar that changes the magnitude of the vector but not its direction.
hints.Dot Product: A binary operation that takes two vectors and returns a scalar.
hints.Cross Product: A binary operation on two vectors in three-dimensional space that results in a vector which is perpendicular to the plane containing the two original vectors.
hints.Matrix Addition and Subtraction: Operations that add or subtract corresponding elements in two matrices.
hints.Matrix Multiplication: An operation that takes a pair of matrices and produces another matrix, subject to certain conditions.
hints.Determinants: A special number that can be calculated from a square matrix.
hints.Inverse of a Matrix: For a given matrix, the inverse is another matrix such that when the two are multiplied together, the result is the identity matrix.
hints.Systems of Linear Equations: A set of linear equations that all together form a system.
hints.Vector Spaces: A collection of vectors that satisfy a set of axioms including closure under addition and scalar multiplication.
hints.Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Special sets of scalars and vectors associated with a system of linear equations that are particularly useful in systems of differential equations and physics.
hints.Orthogonal Vectors: Two vectors are orthogonal if their dot product equals zero, meaning they are at right angles to each other.
hints.Linear Transformations: A mapping between two vector spaces that preserves the operations of vector addition and scalar multiplication.
hints.Rank of a Matrix: The maximum number of linearly independent column vectors in the matrix, which is the same as the maximum number of linearly independent row vectors.
